comments.body: This feels potentially fragile. Maybe a sleep loop instead...?
I've done a `grep -r sleep test/`  and it seems the norm

doesn't mean it's a good idea? :+)

I suppose we can more broadly look at that later.
how the pod dies if it's in a continuous loop?
I vaguely remember that this is on purpose, maybe @neolit123 knows more about this topic of using `sleep` instead a loop
why not `sleep infinite` and keep the `defer fr.PodClient().DeleteSync...`?

I've tried it locally and was waiting forever , I didn't go deeper but the deletesync never killed the pod.
I think I read somewhere that the e2e framework handled the pod cleaning, that's why I removed the deletesync calls

i guess deleting `Namespace: fr.Namespace.Name,` should handle that, yes.

> I've tried it locally and was waiting forever ,

but note after 600ms, that the Pod enters a "Completed" phase instead of "Running" if that matters for the test.

`man sleep`

> Pause  for NUMBER seconds.  SUFFIX may be 's' for seconds (the default),

the test is limited to `postFinTimeoutSeconds = 30 s` plus the time to spawn the pods, so 600s seems a safe bet :)

> man sleep

right, i forgot.

> safe bet

if you think so.

> if you think so.

:)

						SecurityContext: &v1.SecurityContext{
							Privileged: &privileged,

comments.body: thanks for fixing typo
should this be a utility method?

I didn't see it used anywhere else, it seems that only conntrack is expanding the IPv6 addresses when writing to a file.
I don't have any preference honestly, just thought this was the simplest way
Can you add a `[Privileged]` to this test's name in the `ginkgo.It` call above?
done

@spiffxp I think that this was the problem,  the exec pod was executing with pause, it then executes a command in a goroutine https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/86924/files#diff-e99584717e21a274f44c98f0c97a3182L232
This way it is cleaned when the test ends

			framework.ExpectNoError(err)

comments.body: Is there no other way to accomplish what this test is trying to do?

Yeah, that is ideal.
Unfortunately I cannot find the alternative way instead of skipping.

necro-ing a bit but ...
I'm pretty sure was not the correct way to do this, I definitely have conntrack and a working kind cluster on my machine but this file does not exist even on the host. (ubuntu 20.04)

it looks to me like you're expected to use `conntrack -L`  instead of reading this file.

see e.g. https://github.com/netdata/netdata/issues/161#issue-145492475

cc @aojea

interesting, thanks for the pointer, it also  mentions

> I see, yes. And to be sure, I just confirmed that accessing /proc/net/stat/* does not put any load on the system, while accessing /proc/net/nf_conntrack directly takes a very very long time (40 seconds on a firewall with 100,000 tracked connection).

that I'd say is the cause of the flakiness in the TCP_CLOSE_WAIT test

I'll submit a new PR to change this
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/90687
